analysis.raw_analysis:
Stage 1 analysis:

1) Transformation type: input and output keep same size (15x15), ratio 1:1.

2) Pattern (works for both): detect the collinear single-cell 1s with a constant (dr,dc) step (diagonal). Preserve those 1s and extend the arithmetic progression in the same step direction until leaving the grid, placing color 2 at each new position; background 0 unchanged.

3) Key changes:
- Ex1: keeps 1s at (0,0),(4,4),(8,8); adds 2 at (12,12).
- Ex2: keeps 1s at (1,1),(3,3),(5,5); adds 2s at (7,7),(9,9),(11,11),(13,13).

=== INPUT-INPUT COMPARISONS ===
- Same: a few isolated 1-cells lie on a straight diagonal with constant step (dr,dc). Grid size 15x15.
- Different: (dr,dc) and starting positions differ (ex1 dr=dc=4; ex2 dr=dc=2).

=== OUTPUT-OUTPUT COMPARISONS ===
- Exactly same: all original 1 cells remain. New cells of color 2 extend the same diagonal beyond the last 1 until the grid edge. No other changes.

=== INPUT-OUTPUT COMPARISONS ===
- Rule: identify the arithmetic progression of 1s along (dr,dc); preserve them and fill every subsequent cell at +k*(dr,dc) with color 2 until out of bounds.

Reference objects: the isolated blue single cells (value 1) lie on a straight line with a constant step (dr,dc). They stay unchanged and define the sequence origin, direction and stride.

Grid pattern: compute the arithmetic progression of coordinates and extend it past the last blue, placing color 2 at every further step until the grid edge.

Objects: the key recurring objects are the singleton colored cells; the rule copies the sequence forward (no changes to existing blues).

=== GENERAL RULE ===
Step 1: IF a connected region's size is 1 AND its color is 1 THEN mark that single cell as a sequence element.  
Step 2: IF there exist at least two marked sequence elements whose row coordinates and column coordinates each form an arithmetic progression with the same integer difference (i.e., for consecutive elements r_{i+1}-r_i = dr AND c_{i+1}-c_i = dc for the same dr,dc) THEN compute and store the integer step vector (dr,dc) as that common difference.  
Step 3: IF a step vector (dr,dc) has been computed THEN identify an endpoint sequence element as any marked sequence element at (r,c) for which there is no marked sequence element at (r+dr,c+dc).  
Step 4: IF an endpoint sequence element (r,c) is identified THEN set next = (r+dr,c+dc).  
Step 5: IF the cell at position next is inside the grid bounds AND its color is 0 THEN change the color of that cell to 2, set (r,c)=next, compute next=(r+dr,c+dc), AND repeat Step 5 until the computed next is outside the grid bounds.  
Step 6: IF a cell's color is 1 THEN leave that cell's color unchanged (do not overwrite existing 1s).

Step 3: IF a step vector (dr,dc) has been computed THEN identify an endpoint sequence element as any marked sequence element at (r,c) for which there is no marked sequence element at (r+dr,c+dc).

Step 2: IF there exist at least two marked sequence elements whose row coordinates and column coordinates each form an arithmetic progression with the same integer difference (i.e., for consecutive elements r_{i+1}-r_i = dr AND c_{i+1}-c_i = dc for the same dr,dc) THEN compute and store the integer step vector (dr,dc) as that common difference.

Step 6: IF a cell's color is 1 THEN leave that cell's color unchanged (do not overwrite existing 1s).
